quoteFirst: By tokens and signs we found that both of us belong to that great body of men that knows each other as brothers in every corner of the inhabited world. It was he, Dr. Lucretius, who came to my cabin on the morning of the 16th of May, at
quoteLast: , and knocking at the door, said, Father Golden, we are now entering into the harbor of New York, and if you want to enjoy a grand view of the surrounding country you had better come out on the upper bridge. I shall be there waiting for you to explain some of the most beautiful sceneries that you have ever looked upon in your life.
title: Conversion of a High Priest into a Christian Worker
author: Golden, M. (Meletios)

quoteLast: , having been on my feet twenty-six hours. Had a few hours’ sleep and went forward again with ten men, showing them the tracks, etc.
title: A Soldier's Diary
author: Scott, Ralph

quoteLast: the camp is fairly roused, and a little low chatting becomes audible. This is a critical moment. The porters have promised overnight to start early and make a long wholesome march. But, ‘uncertain, coy and hard to please,’ they change their minds, like the fair sex; the cold morning makes them unlike the men of the warm evening, and perhaps one of them has fever.
title: Stirring scenes in savage lands
author: Greenwood, James, 1832-1929

quoteFirst: This is the constellation Corona Borealis, or the Northern Crown. As the hours pass you will see the Crown swing slowly westward, descending gradually toward the horizon, and if you persevere in your observations until
quoteLast: , you will see it set in the north-west. The curve that it describes is concentric with those followed by the Great Dipper and Cassiopeia, but, being farther from the North Star than they are, and at a distance greater than the altitude of the North Star, it sinks below the horizon before it can arrive at a point directly underneath that star.
title: Astronomy in a nutshell
author: Serviss, Garrett Putman, 1851-1929

quoteFirst: After four days’ rest it returned to the trenches, placing two companies in the front line and two companies in reserve, and carrying out inter-company relief. On the 10th of February,
quoteLast: , the enemy launched a bombing attack, and tried to raid the two right posts of the right companies, but it was a half-hearted affair, and the enemy succeeded in reaching the wire in front of our trenches; the Lewis-gun and rifle fire was too strong for them, and none of the bombs they threw reached our men.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

quoteFirst: I glanced at my watch. NO! The time was
quoteLast: He was coming at nine o'clock last night. . . .
title: Life Blood
author: Hoover, Thomas, 1941-

quoteLast: , and I went up with Jack to his hut. Here I got a bit of uneasy sleep, and thence set off to find Hamilton; for the whole staff, with his Excellency, had made haste to reach the camp at Tappan so soon as the general felt reassured as to the safety of West Point.
title:
Hugh Wynne, Free Quaker
Sometime Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel on the Staff of his Excellency General Washington
author: Mitchell, S. Weir (Silas Weir), 1829-1914

quoteLast: we were turned out at a place called Aubury, where we changed carriages and passed the Customs on the Victorian border. All the colonies collect duty from each other, and their mother country.
title: Colonial facts and fictions: Humorous sketches
author: Milne, John, 1850-1913

quoteLast: , the auxiliary cruiser _Sinano Maru_ almost ran into our hospital ships, and it was due to this that the whole fleet was discovered. We were unable to see what had happened, but by the changed character of the messages it became at once apparent that our presence was known.
title:
The Battle of Tsu-shima
between the Japanese and Russian fleets, fought on 27th May 1905
author: Semenov, V. I. (Vladimir Ivanovich), 1867-1910; Lindsay, A. B. (Alexander Bertram), 1872-1914 [Translator]

quoteFirst: "The whole affair was conducted with the utmost decency and decorum; there was the greatest gaiety, cheerfulness and complacency in every countenance. The ball was concluded
quoteLast: and the night was passed in the general satisfaction, without the least incivility offered or offence taken by any one, which is scarce to be said on the like occasions. We are told this was distinguished by the title of the Country Ball.
title: Old Taverns of New York
author: Bayles, W. Harrison (William Harrison), 1841-1929

quoteLast: . Here was Miss Lydia, cool and negligent on the porch, like she'd never had a care in the world; fresh dressed in something white and blue, with her niftiest hammock stockings, and tinkling the ukulele in a bored and petulant manner.
title: Ma Pettengill
author: Wilson, Harry Leon, 1867-1939

quoteFirst: 4 section, which was repulsed and followed up, but the pressing of the counter-attack was prevented by shrapnel. Attacks were also delivered on Quinn’s Post, Courtney’s Post, and along the front of our right section. At
quoteLast: the battle was fairly joined, and a furious cannonade was begun by a large number of enemy guns, including 12-inch and 9.2-inch, and other artillery that had not till then opened. By 9.30 A.M. the Turks were pressing hard against the left of Courtney’s and the right of Quinn’s Post.
title: The Anzac Book
author: Bean, C. E. W. (Charles Edwin Woodrow), 1879-1968 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Wangaratta. I arrived here with five men
quoteLast: We were at once challenged by police, and answered, 'Wangaratta police.' My men were then distributed around the hut, and I got to the tree near the back door of the hut. There was no firing then.
title: The Last of the Bushrangers: An Account of the Capture of the Kelly Gang
author: Hare, Francis Augustus

quoteFirst: I know I tried to pray, begged the Lord to forgive my sins for His great name's sake, and asked for His protecting arm around me, and strength of mind and body to do my duty to my Queen and Country. I then retired for a little rest, until
quoteLast: , when our men were up, and then no more sleep. I wrote a number of letters that morning for poor fellows--some of whom were laid low before mid-day, and others struck down maimed, some to rise no more, long before sunset.
title:
A Soldier's Experience; or, A Voice from the Ranks
Showing the Cost of War in Blood and Treasure. A Personal Narrative of the Crimean Campaign, from the Standpoint of the Ranks; the Indian Mutiny, and Some of its Atrocities; the Afghan Campaigns of 1863
author: Gowing, T. (Timothy), 1834-1908

title: The Battle of the Falkland Islands, Before and After

title: Six prize Hawaiian stories of the Kilohana Art League

quoteFirst: Lieutenant Macdowell, second in command of Hodson's Horse--an eye-witness--says: "The steadiness with which the cavalry confronted this most anxious position for two hours is as deserving of praise as the courage of the infantry who carried the breaches.  At three a.m. we moved down in column of squadrons to the rear of our batteries, and waited there till
quoteLast: , when the enemy advanced from the Lahore gate with two troops of artillery, no end of cavalry, and a lot of infantry, apparently to our front.  I think that they intended to try and take their old position now that we had got theirs.
title: Our Soldiers: Gallant Deeds of the British Army during Victoria's Reign
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880
